floodArea.riverOrSea: River Coly, River Yarty, Umborne Brook

items.message: The risk of flooding in the River Axe Area has now reduced. River levels are falling below levels of concern, however there may be standing water seen for several days. Heavy showers are forecast for Monday and river levels will remain sensitive to any further rainfall. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Flooding is possible this morning on Monday 24th May. The Rivers Clyst and Culm are continuing to rise following the heavy rain on Sunday. Levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river. Further heavy showers are forecast in this area today and we expect the rivers to remain high throughout the day. Take care near the areas of concern and check your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and are ready to respond as required. This message will be updated on Tuesday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers in the Forest of Dean
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.    
Please avoid contact with flood water.

River levels have risen at the Cae Howel river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible  from 09:00 24/05.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peaks:-  Cae Howel 3.4m to 3.6m Monday afternoon 24/05. No flooding is expected at other gauge locations.
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 18:00 on 24/05/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message: River levels remain high at the Farndon river gauge following heavy rainfall and are expected to rise further following rainfall overnight in Wales. We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days, with further showery rain forecast today and tomorrow 25/05/21. Please be aware that access to Townfield Lane could be cut off due to high river levels. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels, and will issue Flood Warnings if necessary. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation. This message will be updated tomorrow, Tuesday 25th May, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Brokenborough river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the weekend.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible until Wednesday 26/05/2021.  We expect flooding to affect the road at Reybridge.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further light showery rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on Tuesday, 25/05/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This alert has been removed as levels continue to fall in the river Ouse at York. Further rainfall is forecast through Sunday night and into Monday, 24/05/21, but this is not currently expected to require the re-issue of this alert. Our incident response staff are continuing to monitor the situation.

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper Derwent has been removed as levels continue to fall. Further showers are expected over the next few days but these should be lighter than those seen over the weekend and are not currently expected to require re-issue of this alert.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.    
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We continue to monitor the situation.
